title: 109_hr1953
content: The Act is titled the "San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that the San Francisco Old Mint, known as the Granite Lady, played a significant role in the nation's history. Established in 1852 to convert miners' gold into coins, the Mint survived the 1906 earthquake and fire, serving as the treasury for disaster relief funds. Coins minted there bear the "S" mark. The San Francisco Old Mint struck rare coins like the 1870-S $3 coin worth over $1,000,000 and the 1894-S dime. The San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin will be the first to honor a U.S. mint. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the San Francisco Old Mint. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90% gold. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. According to title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the San Francisco Old Mint Building, its importance to California and the history of the United States, and its role in rebuilding San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake and fire. Each coin shall include a value designation, the year "2006", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Board of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the San Francisco Mint within a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2006. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include a surcharge: $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for rehabilitating the Historic Old Mint. The Society will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury can continue issuing numismatic items containing 5-cent coins minted in 2004 and 2005 after December 31, 2005.
